title: 115_hr378
content: The Act titled "Bonuses for Cost-Cutters Act of 2017" aims to enhance cost savings. The Act "Bonuses for Cost-Cutters Act of 2017" includes definitions related to wasteful expenses in government accounts. The "Bonuses for Cost-Cutters Act of 2017" allows agencies to pay cash awards to employees who identify wasteful expenses resulting in cost savings. The amendment increases the maximum award amount to $20,000 and includes the Chief Financial Officer in the process. The amendment to the "Bonuses for Cost-Cutters Act of 2017" allows agencies to pay cash awards for the disclosure of fraud, waste, or mismanagement, increasing the maximum award amount to $20,000. It includes the Chief Financial Officer in the process. The amendment allows agencies to propose rescission of potential wasteful expenses identified by employees to the President. If an agency has no Chief Financial Officer, an employee can be designated to make such determinations. Agencies must disclose information on wasteful expenses in the same manner as required for other information under title 31. The section outlines the requirements for disclosing wasteful expenses identified by employees, cash awards provided by agencies, and eligibility criteria for receiving cash awards. The Director of the Office of Personnel Management is responsible for ensuring agency compliance with the cash award program and submitting an annual certification to Congress. The Bonuses for Cost-Cutters Act of 2017 requires the Comptroller General to report on the cost savings and awards program every 3 years for 6 years. Additionally, a technical amendment is made to the table of sections for subchapter II of chapter 45 of title 5, United States Code.
